what: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: MolPad offers visualization dashboard tool designed enhance understanding molecular co-expression works context multi-omics microbiome data. approach involves using cluster network provide initial overview relationships across multiple omics, added functionality interactively zoom specific areas interest. facilitate analysis, ’ve developed focus-plus-context strategy seamlessly connects online curated annotations. dashboard comprises several components, including cluster-level network, bar plot illustrating taxonomic composition, line plot displaying data modalities, table pathway. can see illustration features screenshot.  Additionally, package simplifies entire pipeline creating dashboard. user-friendly design makes accessible even students limited R programming experience.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: Clutering data k-means building group network. Find significant trend patterns datasets. Target interaction groups, taxons, pathways. Visualize distribution features specific pathways group network. Search particular features user-defined labels. Check detailed information feature automatically generated hyperlinks. better overall understanding datasets.

title: What the Package Does (One Line, Title Case)
text: first input list datasets, normalized imputed. second input pathway dataset. Note datasets, first column must ID. information, please check corresponding functions.

title: Introduction
text: Navigating network MolPad dashboard follows three steps demonstrated Fig : First, choose primary functional annotation adjust edge density tuning threshold value importance score. Nodes turnbright green (Fig .) represent clusters containing features chosen functional annotation. Second, brushing network reveals patterns taxonomic composition (Fig .B) typical trajectories (Fig .C). user also zoom specific taxonomic annotations filtering. Third, view feature table (Fig .D) examine drop-options related function annotations, click link online information interested items. interface designed support iterative exploration, encouraging use several steps answer specific questions, like comparing pattern distribution two functions finding functionally important community members metabolizing feature interest.

title: Introduction
text: Fungal gardens serve external digestive system fungus-growing ant, mutualistic fungi genus Leucoagaricus converting plant substrate energy. used naturally evolved fungal garden consortium carrying lignocellulose degradation gradually infected time pathogenic fungus, Escovopsis, dynamic system study, analyzed bacterial taxa present system capture community shifts map detected activity space.

title: Introduction
text: Since microbes can provide defense competitively excluding pathogenic microbes, one question find shifts population compositions metabolic potentials complex microbial consortium response perturbation. studied (pathway, name) MolPad dashboard verified (increasing/decreasing/u shape) pattern (feature). metaproteome data unveiled studied samples enriched plant materials microbial community dominated fungal bacterial species. Leucogaricus main driver lignocellulose degradation (component Carbohydrate metabolism). pathogenic fungus, Escovopsis, proliferated, normalized spectra count native fungal species, Leucogaricus, decreased bacterial members generally increased. Suggesting active community response potential interkingdom interactions impact fungal infection. community lipidome also indicated shifts microbial compositions functions significant trends (adjusted p-value < 0.05) lipid class (.e., phosphatic acids (PA), diacylglycerophosphocholines (PC), diacylglycerophosphoethanolamines (PE), diacylglycerophosphoglycerol (PG), etc.) due infection. Plant alpha-linolenic (18:3) containing lipids, previously found molecular indicators lignocellulose degradation [1], associated native fungal community decreased infection. Conversely, oleic acid (18:1) containing lipids (.e., PA(18:1/18:1), PC(18:1/18:1), PE(18:1/18:1), bacterial odd-chain fatty acids (.e., PE(19:1/19:1); PG(19:1/19:1)) increased infection. Metabolomic data captured depletion metabolites essential fungal growth infection myo-inositol. Phosphoric acid antimicrobial activity bacteria fungi one abundant metabolites detected significantly increased fungal infection, indicating potential interactions among bacteria, native pathogenetic fungi.

title: Introduction
text: process producing cheese, regular washing brine solution aging practice can homogenize microbial communities cheese’ surface facilitate intermicrobial interactions. study analyzed longitudinal data set three washed-rind cheese communities collected cheese ripening.

title: Introduction
text: study revealed highly reproducible microbial succession cheese. bacterial community, Firmicutes dominant beginning, Proteobacteria quickly take domination end ripening. Besides, Cheese C show reproducible establishment Actinobacteria Bacteroidetes separately. verify conclusions MolPad dashboard, analyzed two cheeses(C) three batches week 2~13.

title: Introduction
text: applying dashboard, made extended time series connecting last time point cheese first one cheese C. allowed us track unusual pattern combinations among different species stages. bacterial community larger higher variety patterns, take top four detailed analysis. Groups 10 4 decreasing trends cheeses, include largely Proteobacteria Firmicutes. Groups 3 7 opposite increasing trends, include Actinobacteria Bacteroidetes. Among , Groups 7 4 strongest periodicity, suggesting reproducible tendency corresponding main components. eukaryote community, features followed stable pattern Group 4. Overall, results match research used provide intuitive explanations supporting findings.

title: Generate shiny dashboard — gDashboard
text: data dataframe; output pre_process() cluster list two; output gClusters() annotation dataframe; output gAnnotation() networkres dataframe; output gNetwork() dashboardtitle string. id_colname single string sting vector. column names annoation dataset contains external database IDs. id_type single string sting vector. corresponding database names columns, must choose "KEGG" "GO".

title: Generate shiny dashboard — gDashboard
text: Please ensure columns containing external database IDs adhere following standards: KEGG ID: Begin 'K' followed 5 digits, example, K05685 K06671. GO ID: Begin 'GO:' followed 7 digits, GO:0003674."

title: Generate prediction network — gNetwork
text: gNetwork() generates prediction network functional annotation. every feature, features considered independent variables, top predictors selected based %IncMSE.

title: Generate prediction network — gNetwork
text: clusters list two; output gClusters() ntop number. Pick top n predictors feature. seed number random seed.

title: Generate prediction network — gNetwork
text: assess relationships clusters using Mean Squared Error (MSE) changes resulting random shuffling. gNetwork()'s output includes edge weights node pairs, essential inputs dashboard.

title: Generate prediction network — gNetwork
code: data(test_data) networkres <- gNetwork(test_cluster, ntop = 3) head(networkres) #>      weight IncNodePurity var_names    from #> 1  2.274695     1.0143544   Group_5 Group_1 #> 2  1.626139     0.7277801   Group_3 Group_1 #> 3 -1.540033     0.5645275   Group_4 Group_1 #> 4  5.229531     1.2420219   Group_4 Group_2 #> 5  4.616027     0.8339682   Group_5 Group_2 #> 6  2.323583     1.2926906   Group_1 Group_2 gNetwork_view(networkres)

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
text: pre_process() function aids processing data inputs automatically establishes standardized format future use. allows two types data input: list datasets different sources long dataset containing specified column type. important note dataset, initial column designated IDs, subsequent columns expected contain values measured Time1, Time2, forth.

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
code: pre_process(   data,   typenameList = NULL,   replaceNA = TRUE,   scale = TRUE,   autoColName = "Day_" )

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
text: data list datasets long dataset. typenameList vector dataset names. parameter applicable input format list. scale Logical; TRUE (default), scale datasets row. See also scale_by_row__ autoColName string; NULL (default), automatically set uniform column names datasets.parameter applicable input format list. replaceNa Logical; TRUE (default), replace NA 0.

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
text: long dataset columns ID, Time1, Time2, ..., type.

title: Pre-processing datasets — pre_process
text: consider two distinct scenarios application: *one scenario, individuals collect several datasets various aspects instruments objects. example, might separately detecting lipids, metabolites, peptides specific soil sample. *scenario, data uniform quality, can categorized larger groups exhibit significant differences. cases, pre_process() function serves valuable versatile tool. Yet, function optional generating dashboard. Users can perform processing long format matches required output. However, mindful number samples (timepoints) must greater 5 avoid potential errors subsequent prediction section.

title: Scale by row — scale_by_row__
text: Scales values sample, row independently processed.

title: Scale by row — scale_by_row__
text: input expected data frame first column ID following columns containing observations different time points. ID column remains unaltered, columns double (dbl) format scaled.

title: Test data — test_data
text: synthetically generated dataset created basic testing purposes.

title: Test data — test_data
text: two datasets: data annotations

title: Test data — test_data
text: data frame 100 rows 12 variables: ID row ID T1~T10 count value 10 timepoints type type ~D

title: Test data — test_data
text: data frame 100 rows 5 variables: ID row ID GO_ID go ID KEGG_ID kegg ID system primary lable: 'Integumentary System', 'Skeletal System', 'Muscular System', 'Nervous System', 'Endocrine System', 'Cardiovascular System', 'Lymphatic System', 'Respiratory System', 'Digestive System', 'Urinary System' class secondary label: 'antibodies', 'contractile proteins', 'enzymes', 'hormonal proteins', 'structural proteins', 'storage proteins', 'transport proteins'

title: Transpose dataframe — transpose_dataframe__
text: function transposes provided data frame, using values first column new column names.

title: Transpose dataframe — transpose_dataframe__
text: expected input data frame first column serves Time, subsequent columns contain observations various features.

title: Transpose dataframe — transpose_dataframe__
code: a <- data.frame("Day"=c("Day1","Day2","Day3"),"feature_1" =c(1,2,3),"feature_2" =c(0,4,1),"feature_3" =c(1,1,0)) a #>    Day feature_1 feature_2 feature_3 #> 1 Day1         1         0         1 #> 2 Day2         2         4         1 #> 3 Day3         3         1         0 transpose_dataframe__(a) #>   Day1 Day2 Day3 #> 1    1    2    3 #> 2    0    4    1 #> 3    1    1    0
